awd_titl_txt: Non-local Kinetic Collisional Transport: Analysis and Numerical Methods
awd_abstract_narration:
The overall objective of this research is to develop accurate mathematical modeling and methods of numerical simulation for an array of diverse natural and engineering processes of fundamental scientific interest, such as evolution of plasmas in fusion devices, dynamics of very cold gases in the intermediate transition to form Bose-Einstein condensates,  hot-electron transport in semiconductor devices, design of nanostructures for the solar generation of hydrogen, dynamics of reacting molecular mixtures associated to aerospace dynamics of re-entry problems. All these phenomena are unified by the underlying structure of their mathematical description that involves "particles" interactions of different kinds. A study of these mathematical structures is the principal subject of this project. Modelling and simulation will be based on data obtained by accurate crystallographic calculations, taking into account atomistic corrections, the presence of rough media, etc. Same of the techniques that we will develop are pertinent to exciting new applications in biological and social sciences. They include modeling of self-organized flows in "particle" swarms like birds or fish, emerging consensus in population dynamics, multi-agent information transfer and social information dynamics in internet, to name a few. 

Research goals of the project comprise a broad program in the development of analytical and numerical tools associated with statistical transport equations at the core of applied mathematics in probability, statistics applied to chemistry, physics and to an extent, to social dynamics as well. They concern the modeling of complex interactions systems yielding kinetic frameworks associated to Markovian processes of birth-death dynamics. Such statistical approaches lead to nonlinear integro-differential systems of equations of collisional classical or quantum Boltzmann or Smoluchowski type. Many of these models appear in the collisional theory of semi-classical transport for short- and long-range particle interactions models that describing self-consistent phenomena at nano and mesoscales.  New tools from nonlinear analysis as well as new computational strategies will be developed to address long-time behavior, stability and decay rates to stationary modes, as well as qualitative behavior of numerical solutions and optimal computational strategies.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: ICES - The Univerisity of Texas at Austin

por.por_cntn:
This funded project has focused in five major areas on different aspects of rigorous mathematical analysis and components of computational numerical approximations associated to the following specific broad set of problems:

1. Analytical methods and numerical approximating schemes for the non-linear homogeneous collisional Boltzmann transport models for a single or multi-specie gas components including rigorous stability, error estimates and decay rate to statistical equilibrium analysis and numerical simulations.

2. Mean field theory analysis for the coupling of quantum gas and condensation modeled by means of Quantum Boltzmann-condensation systems for bosons at very low temperature.

3. Spectral energy models for internal waves in stratified ocean flows modeled by weak turbulence kinetic collisional flows as functions of spectral energies.  

4. Time dynamics for Boltzmann-Poisson systems, in the modeling of semiconductor hot electron transport, by the coupling of quantum numerical schemes to deterministic collisional kinetic solvers of five dimensional Hamiltonian transport (2D in physical space – 3D in energy space) with rough boundary conditions.

5. Deterministic solvers for the non-linear Boltzmann transport and Landau collisional models for plasma mean field systems for weak magnetic fields.  Error estimates and numerical calculations of entropic decay.

6. Coupling of a the Navier Stokes equations to a Boltzmann collisional gas in spray flow models, by means of coalescence dynamics.

The major accomplished outcomes fulfilled the majority of this proposal’s set goals that committed to the to study and development of deep analytical understanding of the underlying problems encompassed with the development of  nouvelle approximation and computational techniques that can be fully mathematical analyzed to pass the validation and verification criteria by being verified by rigorous analysis methods of the proposed schemes, as well as verified by experimental data and the computational output of such models.

These six broad group of problems have in common their relations to areas of collisional kinetic transport theory models applied to classical rarefied monoatomic gas models for multispecies mixtures, to plasmas mean field systems, to gas flow dynamics in biochemistry systems,  to a recent applications ranging from social networks, to multi-agent dynamics, to quantitative finance. All these models share the characterization of statistical dynamics flows for interactive particle systems whose transport properties of probability densities with non- linear and non-local terms given by multiplicatively interacting stochastic binary processes.

This project funded three PhD graduate students, one male and two females, one of them of Hispanic descent. One of them got his PhD in April 2021, and the other two will complete it in August 2021 and in December 2021. Two of the have accepted jobs in the innovative Information Technology workforce while the third has chose an academic path.

The PI and these three funded individuals disseminated their results in conferences lectures at meetings and academic institutions at national and international levels. Several publications are a direct outcome of this funded effort.

 


Last Modified: 09/12/2021
Modified by: Irene M Gamba
